text.p: Xerox Corp. launched a line of four high-speed digital copiers Tuesday that can be connected to computer networks for printing, scanning and faxing.
Xerox Chief Executive Officer Paul Allaire said the company had reached "a digital critical mass" and has "embraced a digital future" with the unveiling of the new machines.

The Xerox Document Centre 220 and 230 models, which can copy 20 and 30 pages per minute, respectively, are currently available with a facsimile upgrade in the United States, Canada and parts of Europe.
The 220 model's list price is $8,600 and the 230 is listed at $10,500.
The other two models, the Document Centre 240 and 265 will be available in the second half of 1997.
Allaire said he expected revenues for the new products to reach $2 billion "over time."
The new copiers' components are all recyclable or reusable, the company said. They also include intuitive touch screens and 80 percent fewer replacable parts.
"This is a very important product announcement for them," said B. Alex Henderson, a Prudential Securities analyst. "It's a very important element of their corporate strategy."
"Digital is where the future growth is," said Pete Enderlin, a Smith Barney analyst, adding that its digital products now make up about 30 percent of total revenues.
"They will account for all the growth going forward."
Digital copiers represent big growth potential for Xerox.
Jonathan Rosenzweig of Salomon Brothers estimated in a recent report that digital product revenues will grow 22 percent in the company's first quarter.
This compares with Xerox's total revenue growth of 7 percent in the fourth quarter. Xerox is expected to report first quarter results on April 22.
